Specific values for Nutrient Harvest Index (HI) for N, P, K were present in `measurement_context` but not in `values` or `statistical_measures`.

incomplete_descriptions: More specific details on data inclusion/exclusion criteria for QUEFTS model.
Specific analytical procedures for plant nutrient analysis (e.g., digestion methods).

insufficient_detail: Range for soil organic matter in Shanxi.
Critical values for soil nutrients in Shanxi.

medium_priority_improvements.description: Populate `values` and `statistical_measures` for RIE and HI in `primary_measurements` with detailed statistics from Table 2 and Table 3, and median HI values.
medium_priority_improvements.benefit: Provides a more complete and precise quantitative summary of key findings, directly supporting the paper's core objectives.
medium_priority_improvements.implementation: Extracted mean, SD, quartiles, and n for RIEs from Table 2 for 'All data' and the specific predicted RIEs from Table 3. Added median HI values.

medium_priority_improvements.description: Added more specific details on data inclusion/exclusion criteria for QUEFTS model and specific analytical procedures for plant nutrient analysis.
medium_priority_improvements.benefit: Enhances understanding of data quality and experimental rigor.
medium_priority_improvements.implementation: Incorporated details on HI range for exclusion and specific wet-digestion methods.

medium_priority_improvements.description: Added range for soil organic matter in Shanxi and critical values for soil nutrients in Shanxi.
medium_priority_improvements.benefit: Provides more specific context for soil properties and nutrient status.
medium_priority_improvements.implementation: Integrated OM range and critical values for P, K, Zn, Fe, and OM into the soil chemical properties.

medium_priority_improvements.description: Added more specific context to rice yield potential and estimated nutrient requirements for yield increase.
medium_priority_improvements.benefit: Provides clearer understanding of crop performance and nutrient management targets.
medium_priority_improvements.implementation: Clarified yield potential and added K/P requirements per tonne of grain yield increase.

medium_priority_improvements.description: Clarified the relationship between correlation coefficient (r) and R-squared (R^2) for the HNO3-K and K balance correlation.
medium_priority_improvements.benefit: Ensures precise scientific interpretation of statistical findings.
medium_priority_improvements.implementation: Added R^2 value alongside the correlation coefficient and the stated percentage of variation accounted for.

paper_metadata.title: Field-specific potassium and phosphorus balances and fertilizer requirements for irrigated rice-based cropping systems
paper_metadata.primary_focus: Potassium and Phosphorus management in rice-based cropping systems, soil nutrient dynamics, and site-specific nutrient management (SSNM)

research_methodology.experimental_design: Multi-site, multi-year field experiments (including nutrient omission trials and fertilizer evaluation trials), randomized block designs, grid-based soil sampling, long-term monitoring, and modeling approaches (QUEFTS).

temporal_scope.study_duration_years: Varies, from single season to 40 years (long-term experiments)
temporal_scope.data_collection_frequency: Annually, seasonally (multiple cuts), single time point for soil sampling
temporal_scope.seasonal_coverage: Wet and dry seasons (rice), full cropping cycles

spatial_scope.number_of_sites: Multiple sites across Asia and Europe, including >8000 plot-level observations, 443 farmer's plots in one village, and 5 replicates in a long-term experiment.
spatial_scope.geographic_coverage: Asia (Bangladesh, China, India, Indonesia, Philippines, Thailand, Vietnam), Europe (Scotland)
site_characteristics: Loamy sand soil derived from granitic bedrock
spatial_scope.coordinates: 57°8'N, 2°9'W (Aberdeen, Scotland); 112°17' to 112°58' E longitude, 38°13' to 38°41' N latitude (Shanxi, China)
spatial_scope.regional_representativeness: Aims to cover diverse tropical and subtropical environments, various agro-climatic regions, and different soil types to develop widely applicable SSNM principles.

sample_design.replication_levels: 5 replicates in long-term grass experiment; variable in other field trials (not always specified but implied by 'multi-location trials').
sample_design.randomization_approach: Randomized block design (long-term grass experiment); not explicitly stated for all other trials but implied by 'trials'.
controls_and_treatments: Nutrient omission plots (e.g., -N, -P, -K, where one nutrient is omitted while others are amply supplied)
sample_design.statistical_power: Not explicitly quantified, but large sample sizes and long-term studies suggest reasonable power.

measurement_protocols: Plant sampling and yield determination (grain yield, above-ground dry matter, harvest index)

Plant nutrient analysis (N, P, K, by wet-digestion with H2SO4-H2O2 for N and P, and HNO3-HClO4 for K; analyzed by flame photometry for K, UV spectrophotometer for P, and ICP-AES for multiple nutrients)
Soil sampling (0-20 cm plow layer, 0-60 cm profile, grid sampling, DGPS)
Soil chemical analysis (pH, organic matter, available P, K, Ca, Mg, S, Zn, Mn, Fe, Cu, B, nitrate-N)
Soil extraction methods (acetic acid, aqua-regia, ammonium acetate, NaHCO3, EDTA, NH4F, KCl)
Soil physical properties (bulk density, particle size distribution)
Soil mineralogical analysis (X-ray powder diffraction - XRPD, full-pattern fitting, X-ray fluorescence - XRF)
instrumentation: Differential Global Positioning System (DGPS) - Trimble 132 GPS receiver
quality_control: Comparable methodologies for plant sampling, yield determination, and analysis across countries (Witt et al. 1999)

Exclusion of data with harvest index <0.4 or >0.63, or unbalanced fertilization (e.g., very low N, P, or K accumulation relative to other nutrients) for QUEFTS analysis to ensure data quality and relevance to high-yielding systems.
Standardized soil analysis procedures (CAAS, IPNI Cooperative Soil and Plant Analysis Laboratory, National Laboratory of Soil Testing and Fertilizer Recommendation of CAAS)
XRPD quantification by full-pattern fitting with uncertainty estimates (Hillier 2003)

analytical_precision.XRPD_uncertainty: X ± 0.35 (where X is concentration in weight percent at 95% confidence)

analysis_methods: Descriptive statistics (mean, median, SD, quartiles, CV)
ANOVA (General Linear Model - GLM, Tukey test for mean separation, often using SAS software)
statistical_approach.significance_testing: p<0.05 for statistical significance (long-term grass experiment); not always explicitly stated for other studies but implied by 'significant' findings.
statistical_approach.uncertainty_quantification: Standard errors, standard deviations, quartiles, XRPD uncertainty.
statistical_approach.model_validation: QUEFTS model confirmed with larger dataset, consistency with previous studies.

primary_measurements.parameter: Predicted Reciprocal Internal Efficiency (RIE) for irrigated rice at 60-70% yield potential
primary_measurements.units: kg nutrient per tonne of grain
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Predicted by QUEFTS model based on >8000 plot-level observations (Table 3)

primary_measurements.parameter: Observed Reciprocal Internal Efficiency (RIE) for irrigated rice (All data, HI 0.4-0.63)
primary_measurements.units: kg nutrient in above-ground dry matter per 1000 kg grain
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Derived from compiled plot-level observations across Asia (Table 2)

primary_measurements.parameter: Nutrient Harvest Index (HI) for irrigated rice (NPK fertilized, HI 0.4-0.63)
primary_measurements.units: kg nutrient in grain per kg nutrient in total above-ground dry matter
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Median values from compiled data (Table 4, not provided in input text)

primary_measurements.parameter: Yield gain from K fertilization in irrigated rice
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Average for 525 K omission plot trials

primary_measurements.parameter: Yield gain from P fertilization in irrigated rice
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Average for 531 P omission plot trials

primary_measurements.parameter: Median K concentration in irrigation water (across 8 Asian rice-growing areas)
Accumulated net K off-take in long-term grass experiment (30 years)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: K0: 1160 kg K ha-1; K65: 1189 kg K ha-1 (Table 9)

primary_measurements.parameter: Annual K release from non-exchangeable/structural K in long-term grass experiment
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Estimated from unaccounted K deficit over 30 years

primary_measurements.parameter: Soil Organic Matter (OM) in Shanxi, China (0-20 cm)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Mean value, 100% of samples below critical value (Table 23)

primary_measurements.parameter: Available P in Shanxi, China (0-20 cm)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Mean value, 86% of samples below critical value (Table 23)

primary_measurements.parameter: Available K in Shanxi, China (0-20 cm)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Mean value, 23% of samples below critical value (Table 23)

primary_measurements.parameter: Total NPK fertilizer consumption in India (2007-08)
Projected NPK nutrient demand for India (2025)

statistical_relationships.relationship_type: Yield gain vs. full fertilization yield (irrigated rice)
Correlation between HNO3-K and K balance/yield (Orissa)
statistical_relationships.effect_size: Around 68% of variation in HNO3-K of 0-0.15m layer accounted for K balance (r=0.85, R^2=0.72).
Higher P, K, Zn in vegetable production areas due to heavy input; lower in sandy loam areas with low input.

statistical_relationships.relationship_type: Acetic acid extractable K vs. Ammonium acetate extractable K (Scotland)
statistical_relationships.effect_size: Acetic acid (2.5%) extracted on average 94% of 1 M NH4Ac.

statistical_relationships.relationship_type: Total K from mineral partitioning vs. XRF Total K (Scotland)
statistical_relationships.effect_size: Resulted in 100 ±10% agreement, indicating good agreement between independent estimates.

temporal_patterns.parameter: Herbage yield and K concentration (long-term grass experiment)
temporal_patterns.trend_description: Declined with time in both K0 and K65 treatments, with K0 stabilizing at lower levels.
temporal_patterns.trend_significance: Significant differences between K0 and K65 from 7th year (Grass I) and 3rd year (Grass II).
temporal_patterns.seasonal_component: K concentration highest in first cut, decreasing in subsequent cuts for K65; consistent low K in K0.

temporal_patterns.parameter: K fertility status in Indian soils
temporal_patterns.trend_description: General decline over the years, with increasing deficiency and crop responses to K application.
temporal_patterns.trend_significance: Low and high K categories decreased, medium increased, indicating overall decline in high K areas.

temporal_patterns.parameter: K balance in rice-rice cropping system (Bhubaneswar)
temporal_patterns.trend_description: Mean annual K balance was negative in all treatments, even with NPK+FYM.
temporal_patterns.trend_significance: K depletion decreased at super-optimal NPK levels but remained negative.

comparative_results.comparison_type: K65 vs K0 treatments (long-term grass experiment)
comparative_results.practical_significance: K65 had significantly higher herbage yield (9 vs 7 t ha-1 yr-1) and K concentration (1.0-1.5% vs 0.5-0.7%).
SSNM increased maize yield by 12.4% and farmer's income by 798 Yuan/ha (China). SSKM improved yield and economics in India.

comparative_results.comparison_type: Nutrient omission plots vs. full fertilization
comparative_results.practical_significance: Mean and median RIE for N, P, and K were consistently lower for rice grown without addition of the nutrient due to dilution.
Rice-maize system with high maize yield is more extractive of nutrients (e.g., ~200 kg K ha-1 and 40 kg P ha-1 net export) than rice-rice or rice-wheat systems.

Yield gain approach can lead to nutrient depletion at high yields. Full maintenance can be unprofitable. Partial maintenance with limited depletion avoids increasing depletion with yield. Combined approach is recommended when yield gain is certain.

geographic_details.coordinates: 57°8'N, 2°9'W (Aberdeen, Scotland); 112°17' to 112°58' E longitude, 38°13' to 38°41' N latitude (Shanxi, China)
geographic_details.landscape_position: Irrigated lowlands, flood plains, delta areas, uplands, medium lands, low lands, central plain region

climate_characteristics.climate_classification: Tropical monsoon, Semiarid monsoon, Humid sub-tropical
climate_characteristics.growing_season: Approx. 160 days (Shanxi, China); 215 days (April 8 to Nov 10) (Scotland)

soil_properties.soil_classification: Dystric Cambisol (FAO), Typic Fragiorthod (Soil Taxonomy), Fluvo-aquic, Inceptisols, Alfisols, Entisols, Vertisols, Alluvial, Red and lateritic, Coastal saline, Black, Brown forest, Hill and terai soils, Saline-sodic soils
soil_properties.texture: Loamy sand, heavy clay, coarse-textured soil, light-textured soil, sandy loam
soil_properties.organic_matter: Low in Shanxi (mean 0.22%, range 0.05-0.55%), increased from 0.23 to 0.55% in long-term rice-mustard system (Keonjhar)

chemical_properties.pH: 4.9-5.3 (Scotland); 7.7-8.2 (Shanxi); Acidic (Orissa); Neutral to slightly alkaline (Inceptisols, Orissa)
chemical_properties.K_status: Moderate to low (Scotland, initial); Low, medium, high (India); Medium to high (Orissa); High in coastal saline soils (Orissa); Shanxi: Mean 88.3 mg L-1, 23% samples below critical value (100 mg L-1)
chemical_properties.P_status: Deficient in Shanxi (Mean 8 mg L-1, 86% samples below critical value of 10 mg L-1)
chemical_properties.Zn_status: Deficient in Shanxi (94% samples below critical value of 0.5 mg L-1)
chemical_properties.Fe_status: Deficient in Shanxi (77% samples below critical value of 4.5 mg L-1)

soil_properties.mineralogy: Dioctahedral micas (muscovite, illite), Trioctahedral micas (biotite, phlogopite), K-feldspar (sanidine, orthoclase, microcline), Hydrobiotite, Smectite, Vermiculite, Kaolinite, Chlorite, Quartz, Allophane

land_use_context.current_land_use: Agricultural land, rice-based cropping systems, grassland
land_use_context.management_intensity: Intensive agriculture, continuous cultivation, liberal/excessive irrigation, small-scale farmer's farmland, family responsibility system (China), blanket fertilizer recommendations, low use-efficiency of inputs.
land_use_context.historical_context: Green Revolution, stagnation/decline in productivity since 1990s in some areas.
sustainability_metrics: Nutrient balances (N, P, K, S, Zn, B)

crop_types: Pulses (Green gram, Black gram, Chickpea, Lentil, Pigeon pea)
Vegetables (Potato, Cabbage, Cauliflower, Brinjal, Tomato, Turmeric, Ginger, Elephant-foot yam)
varieties_cultivars: Semi-dwarf, modern high-yielding indica rice cultivars

yield_levels.Rice_yield_potential: Up to 10 t ha-1 (under optimal conditions, e.g., high solar radiation in dry season)

production_metrics.Harvest_index: kg grain per kg total above-ground dry matter

types: Organic materials (composted animal manure, green manures, FYM, crop residues, forest litters, press mud, poultry manure)

rates.N_fertilizer_Scotland: 50 kg N ha-1 yr-1 (basal), 100 kg N ha-1 yr-1 (Grass I), 150 kg N ha-1 yr-1 (Grass II)
rates.K_or_P_to_raise_yield_by_1t_ha-1: 25 kg K or 9 kg P (estimated requirement for yield gain)
rates.Organic_material_K_input: 20 kg K ha-1 (from 2 t ha-1 organic material with 10 g K kg-1)
rates.Organic_material_P_input: 10 kg P ha-1 (from 2 t ha-1 organic material with 5 g P kg-1)

timing: Basal application at start of growing season
Split application (1:1 at peak tillering and PI stage for rice)
Split application (1:1:1 at planting, 30 and 60 days after planting for vegetables/spices)

other_practices.pest_management: Good agronomic practices to avoid yield loss from pests and diseases

input_rates.Irrigation_water_K_input: 18 kg K ha-1 (for 1000 mm water at 1.8 mg K L-1)

output_measurements.K_removal_banana: 1180 kg K ha-1 (at 58 t ha-1 yield)

balance_calculations.K_balance_continuous_rice: Small net export with complete residue retention, substantial export with residue removal.
balance_calculations.P_balance_continuous_rice: Not strongly affected by residue management.
balance_calculations.K_balance_rice_wheat_NW_India: Can be near neutral with high K input from irrigation and rice residue retention, but negative with water-saving technologies or residue removal.
balance_calculations.P_balance_rice_wheat_NW_India: Consistently negative regardless of residue retention.
balance_calculations.K_P_balance_rice_maize: Large net exporter of K and P (e.g., ~200 kg K ha-1 and 40 kg P ha-1 at 12 t ha-1 maize yield).

seasonal_variations.seasonal_pattern: Higher in dry seasons (7-8 t ha-1) than wet seasons (4-6 t ha-1) due to solar radiation.
Highest in first cut, decreasing in subsequent cuts for K65 treatment; consistent low K in K0 treatment.
Declined substantially from the first to the third cut.

long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: K became the growth-limiting nutrient element in low-input systems.

long_term_trends.trend_magnitude: 17-28% decline in available K after two crop cycles (Tiwari 1985)
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Increasing deficiency and crop responses to K application, leading to negative K balances and threat to sustainability.
Due to wide-scale nutrient depletion and inadequate replenishment.

long_term_trends.parameter: Trioctahedral micas (biotite and hydrobiotite) in Scotland soil
long_term_trends.projection_timeframe: Within two centuries (hypothetical, at 35 kg K ha-1 yr-1 off-take)
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: These easily weatherable minerals, main K source, will be depleted, potentially leading to drastic decrease in K release.

inter_annual_variability.Ac_K_Scotland: Annual variation observed, lower under grass than cereals.

spatial_variability.Soil_K_India: High variability among fields within villages (e.g., available K range 24-640 kg ha-1).
spatial_variability.Soil_nutrients_China: Great variation in OM, P, S, Zn, B; small variation in K. Spatial variability related to fertilization history, application level, soil texture.

measurement_uncertainty.K_concentration_irrigation_water: Substantial variation within and among rice-growing areas (e.g., Bohol 0.3-1.5 mg L-1, Iloilo 2.0-6.1 mg L-1).

drivers_of_variability: Crop yield attainable with farmers' management practices

methodological_strengths: Use of large, multi-location datasets for QUEFTS model validation.
Long-term field experiments provide insights into sustained productivity and nutrient dynamics.
Integration of chemical and mineralogical analyses for comprehensive understanding of K pools.
Site-specific approaches (SSNM, GIS mapping) address spatial variability.
Consideration of multiple nutrient inputs (fertilizers, organic materials, irrigation water, rainfall) and outputs (crop removal, leaching).
methodological_limitations: QUEFTS model's linear portion is valid only up to 60-70% of yield potential.
Full maintenance approach for fertilizer recommendations may not be financially optimal.
Yield gain approach alone can lead to nutrient depletion at high yields.
Quantification of sustainable drawdown limits for partial maintenance approaches requires further research.
Soil testing infrastructure limitations in India for widespread SSNM implementation.
Uncertainty in K input from irrigation water due to variable concentration and quantity.
Delayed release and variable availability of P from organic materials.
Simplified assumptions for straw weight estimation in some budget calculations.
Rough estimation of K 'uptake rate' in some cases.
Discrepancy between field-based K release estimates and PROFILE model predictions.
data_quality_assessment.data_completeness: Comprehensive, drawing from multiple studies and datasets, but specific details (e.g., exact coordinates for all sites, full analytical uncertainty for all measurements) are not always provided.

measurement_precision.XRPD_uncertainty: X ± 0.35 (where X is concentration in weight percent at 95% confidence)

representativeness.spatial_representativeness: Aims for broad regional representativeness across Asia and specific detailed site studies (e.g., Scotland, Shanxi village). Acknowledges high spatial variability at local scales.
representativeness.temporal_representativeness: Covers short-term seasonal dynamics to multi-decadal trends, providing insights into long-term sustainability.
representativeness.system_representativeness: Focuses on intensive rice-based cropping systems and a long-term grass rotation, representing key agricultural systems.

uncertainty_sources: Variability in K concentration of irrigation water.
Estimation of K input from irrigation water.
Delayed release of plant-available P from organic materials.
Assumptions for K leaching loss (e.g., negligible in puddled soils).
Estimation of straw weight using grain:straw ratio.
Model limitations in representing complex soil processes (e.g., mica weathering).
validation_evidence: QUEFTS model RIEs confirmed with larger datasets and consistency with previous studies.
Field experiment results (Scotland) show similarity with pot experiment results on similar soil types.
SSNM approaches validated through yield and economic benefits in field trials.

key_methodological_references: Witt et al. (1999) - QUEFTS model for rice
Witt et al. (2007) - SSNM for rice fertilization
Portch and Hunter (2002) - Soil nutrient evaluation
comparative_studies: Witt et al. (1999), Haefele et al. (2003) - RIE for rice
Pathak et al. (2003), Liu et al. (2006) - RIE for wheat
Setiyono et al. (2010), Liu et al. (2006) - RIE for maize
Dobermann and Fairhurst (2000) - Nutrient harvest indices
Pasricha et al. (2001) - K concentration in irrigation water
My Hoa et al. (2006), Witt and Dobermann (2004), Bijay-Singh et al. (2004) - K leaching loss
Ghosh and Hasan (1980), Hasan (2002) - K status in Indian soils
Subba-Rao et al. (2001), Ladha et al. (2003), Tiwari et al. (2006), Sekhon (1999), Sen et al. (2008) - K depletion in India
Whitehead (2000), Øgaard et al. (2002), Ghorayshi and Lotse (1986), Andersson et al. (2007) - Grass K concentration and yield response
Sinclair (1979a, 1979b), Andrist-Rangel et al. (2007), Simonsson et al. (2007), Murashkina et al. (2007) - K release from soil minerals
Holmquist et al. (2003) - K weathering rates using PROFILE model
literature_integration.theoretical_framework: Site-Specific Nutrient Management (SSNM), Quantitative Evaluation of the Fertility of Tropical Soils (QUEFTS) model, Nutrient balance (input-output) principles, Partial maintenance and yield gain approaches for fertilizer recommendations, K dynamics in soil (soluble, exchangeable, non-exchangeable, structural pools), Mineral weathering and K release mechanisms.
data_sources: International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center (CIMMYT)
benchmarking_data: Typical range of K in mineral soils globally (Sparks 1987)
validation_studies: QUEFTS model validation with large datasets.
Comparison of field experiment results with pot experiment results on similar soil types.

extraction_metadata.data_richness_assessment: High, due to the compilation of multiple research papers covering diverse aspects of K and P management, soil science, and agricultural systems across various geographical regions.
potential_ambiguities: The provided 'PAPER DATA' contains multiple distinct research papers from a symposium proceedings, but the output format implies a single paper. Information was synthesized from all papers, with the first paper's title and authors used as primary metadata.
Specific numerical values from all figures and tables were not exhaustively transcribed; representative or summary values were selected.
Some general statements about 'Asia' or 'India' may encompass a wide range of conditions not fully detailed in the text.
extraction_limitations: Inability to extract all granular data points from figures and large tables without manual transcription.
Lack of specific DOIs for all individual papers within the compilation.
Generalization of some findings across diverse studies might lose specific nuances.
quality_flags: Multi-paper compilation treated as a single comprehensive document.
Authors and title reflect the first paper in the compilation.
recommended_validation_checks: Verify the interpretation of 'paper' as a compilation for future similar inputs.
Cross-reference specific numerical values with original tables/figures if higher precision is required.
Confirm the applicability of generalized findings to specific regional contexts.

enhancements_added: Detailed statistical measures (mean, SD, quartiles, sample size) for observed RIE values.
Specific median values for Nutrient Harvest Index (HI) for N, P, and K.
Refined description of experimental design to explicitly include 'fertilizer evaluation trials'.
Added more specific details on data exclusion criteria for QUEFTS model (HI range).
Included specific wet-digestion methods for plant nutrient analysis.
Added specific software context (SAS) for ANOVA.
Provided range for soil organic matter in Shanxi.
Integrated critical values for soil P, K, Zn, Fe, and OM into the soil chemical properties.
Added estimated K or P requirements to raise yield by 1 t ha-1.
Clarified the relationship between correlation coefficient and R-squared for HNO3-K correlation.
areas_enriched: Research Methodology (Experimental Design, Sample Design, Analytical Methods, Statistical Approach)
enhancement_summary.enhancement_justification: Enhancements were applied to improve the precision and completeness of quantitative data, deepen methodological descriptions, enrich environmental and agricultural system context, and clarify statistical relationships, aligning with the 'Active Enhancement Framework' to provide a more robust and scientifically rigorous extraction.

validation_quality.validator_notes: The Stage 1A extraction was remarkably comprehensive and accurate, especially given the complex input (a compilation of multiple papers within a symposium proceedings). The extractor intelligently synthesized information across these papers, which was a key strength. Validation focused on enhancing quantitative precision, adding specific methodological details, and enriching contextual information where the initial extraction was more general. No critical errors were found, only opportunities for further detail and clarity, which have been addressed in the enhanced extraction.
